reviewText:
When Dystopia came out in 2005 as a mod for the then brand-spankin'-new Half-Life 2, the screen shots looked cool enough that I decided to use a gigantic chunk of my internet's monthly download limit (gg, Aussie internet) to give it a try.

What followed absolutely set my personal bench mark for online FPS games for the next decade.

It may be just a mod, and it may have been released by a small team- but make no mistake. 10 years later, there hasn't been a single multiplayer game released that even comes remotely close to touching Dystopia in terms of how good it is. Halo and CoD with their multi-million dollar budgets? Get that ♥♥♥♥ out of here. It's not even on the same planet, and I say that as a player of both. That this mod died out never having recieved the attention it deserved is one of gaming's biggest unknown tragedies.

The split objective system which sees each team attempting to take objectives in both the real world and the cyber world requires a level of coordination and teamwork that no FPS has even attempted to recreate since. You can dominate on the field as much as you want, blasting the other team to kingdom come as soon as they respawn- but unless you have a guy in cyberspace that knows what he's doing to get those doors open for you, you aren't going anywhere near the objective, sorry. The thrill of successfully sneaking behind enemy lines to find a hacking terminal that you can use to quickly unlock an unwatched backdoor or call an elevator to let in your friends with the big guns is a huge rush.

The class system lets you choose from a standard 3-class list (light, medium, heavy) each with it's own possible loadouts. Maybe you'll be a light cloaked stealth guy with hacking gear. Maybe you'll be a walking behemoth with a rocket launcher on one arm and a pneumatic fist to punch people's heads off on the other. The weapons are balanced nicely and there's no 'perfect' loadout that trumps them all, it's just important to have the right one at the right time.

Dystopia remains to this day the only game I would unflinchingly give a 10/10. Download it. Tell your friends. Bring it back.

I started playing this game in 2006, and stopped a few years ago so this review is maybe a bit dated. I've played a lot of games like most of you so I have some reference.

This was the most fun I've ever had in a FPS, let alone game, ever. I can't even think of a game that was more fun than Dystopia beta U4-U5 or comes even close. Before steam started tracking play time, I must of had at least 500 hours in this game. I tried explaining to someone how fun this game was a few days ago but it was just lost on them.

As previous reviewers have stated there were certain elements to the game that made it so fun like sneaking into enemy base and backdoor hacking to turn the turrets on the other team. Or trying to sneak in while invisible to press first objective switch in vaccine. It was just so thrilling. This game required team work to win but was niche enough to have a great community of players who knew what they were doing since this was back in the day before mods were so streamlined though steam. Which ment that it was a 10 v 10 of players who knew each other and knew how to play the game which made for really fun games. The maps were very well designed too (I played vaccine for 6 months as the only map in the mod at the time).

Even the weapons and body mods were unique and fun. The laser rifle required you to hold it down to charge it and release when you wanted to shoot which made it really balanced, Same thing with the other weapons, they were really gratifying. For a mod in 2006 that had invisiblity, thermal vision, healing, leg jumpers, etc made by a random devteam, the whole game seemed very balanced within the first 2 updates, given the amount of upgrade and weapon variations.

I'm probably just rambling on in this review because I really can't pinpoint what made this game so great. There's a hundred games like it but still nothing that comes near it. Maybe it's just nostalgia about a simpler time with games but I hope not because that would mean that I will never have as much fun as I did back in 2007 playing video games. I'm downloading it now.

Dystopia is a team-based, first-person shooter video game.
The gameplay of Dystopia is objective-based, in which both teams fight against each other to complete a series of objectives within a set amount of time to win the round. As either Punk Mercenaries or Corporate Security Forces the player will fight through the physical world to gain access, via jack-in terminals, to cyberspace. Various things can be done from the cyber-reflection of the map, ranging from opening security doors, disabling cameras, turrets and more.
The graphic is not the best for these days, but it still looks not bad.
Dystopia is a fun, highly customizable first person mod with great team-play in an interesting cyberpunk themed setting.

reviewText:
I have been in and out of this game since meeting one of the level designers back in beta. And I have to say that it is quite possibly the best HL2 mod I have ever played. I would even go as far to say it the best mod to any game, and I love both Killing Floor and Alien Swarm.

The objective based gameplay is something you just don't see enough of these days and the variation in objective design is fantastic. The 3 class system is well balanced and the weapon/implant selection is fantastically varied without having any real automatic 'I WIN' equipment.

The metaspace/cyberspace split has been well executed, with the meatspace maps being generally well laid out, and the cyber maps freedom of movement and physics application being something I've not truly witnesses elsewhere. Both realms rely one each other to either create vulnerabilities in their opponents (like hacking enemy turrets or opening new attack paths) or protecting from weakesses (shutting off poison gas or protecting the defenseless host body while someone hacks). The teamwork potential in the game is incredibly high and most of the time I find its something pubs just naturally fall into without a lot of instruction. This could just be the playerbase the mod attracts, but I've never seen this kind of intricate natural teamwork form anywhere (the closest being TF2 but thats mostly 'stick together, oh we need a medic', not exactly complex)

The only thing truly missing at this point is the graphical style is starting to get a bit dated, but considering it came out a decade ago it still holds up a heck of a lot better than most games from that time. They captured the 'dystopian' cuberpunk aspect really well, with the two factions posessing a unique look and the locations matching the objectives and the universe well.

You should play this, at least a few hours. Get some friends together, or try and find a populated pub server. The fact this mod went so unnoticed is a tragedy, and I feel it had great potential to become a new CS or at least have a standalone release like Killing Floor did.

reviewText:
In many ways Dystopia feels like a HL1 mod. It's clearly old, the maps are dark, the sounds headache inducing, the gameplay is reminiscent of Quake and Unreal Tournament... It's from 2007 and feels like it was meant for HL1.

Game is so blatanly unbalanced I was asked not to use one of the weapons because it was considered overpowered.

Matches oftenly got to a point where every team was so set in their positions it wasn't possible for any of them to get a definitive edge, thus dragging the game way longer than should have been. This is because of the map design and of how respawn works in those games. If you want to see respawn done well see League of Legends and Dota 2.

The level design is often terrible. Many chokepoints will just result in a 20 minutes struggle between the two teams with no clear winner. The lighting is either too bright or too dark, most of the time creating a contrast higher than acceptable. The layouts can be quite confusing as they tend to be really open and identical corridors don't help.

As for the sound the footsteps of the heavy class is too loud, too clunky, too abrupt, etc not to give me a headache, making it impossible for me to play the class for long.

Given such major flaws I cannot recommend this game to anyone but to the most curious and to game designers because it's easier to learn from a bad game than from a good one.

It was made before Orange Box engine and is only a mod, so the lag compensation can be frustrating due to the fact that the developers can't fine-tune the netcode themselves. It has a really steep learning curve, and until recently the tutorial was ineffective for teaching. It's still not perfect, but much more workable. Its graphics and environments are involving and colorful, and the backstory is really evident in everything. I love the cyberspace element, and there is actually some kind of skill in cyberspace too. Cyberbattles are unlike anything I've ever seen, and it really adds a good layer of complexity to the game. As for the normal FPS element of it, Dystopia has some very unique weapons, some of which may not be perfect but overall are quite balanced and the developers clearly care about good design in that regard. This game needs love, and this game needs more of a community, but sadly that probably won't happen.

A unique cyberpunk First Person Shooter based on the same game engine as Valve's Team Fortress 2 and Portal. Players join up with corporate security forces and suburban terrorist groups in this nightmareish look into the future of military cybernetics, where man has melded with machine and become one with the weapons of war.

Dystopia allows players to wage military actions across urban battlefields in a bloody rampage of shattered flesh and steel, with a simultaneous struggle occuring inside the electronic networks of company mainframes by systems crackers, all combining for an intense, multi-layered, team play and objective based thrill ride.

Three degrees of remaining humanity shape the player experience, allowing players to further tailor their gameplay through a selection in personal cybernetics and an arsenal of experimental firearms & close combat weapons.
